story:
Description of Project

The focus on adoption in the national arena is the cute little baby who has now been happily adopted into his new deserving home.  Yet little is known about the women who relinquished their babies to adoption, the women who gave birth to those cute babies.  As a society we assume these women are somehow bad, they are possibly "crack whores" or young women who have gone wrong.  We still keep original mothers shrouded in secrecy and shame often asking, "who would give away their own kid?"  When we talk about adoption and adoptive families we do not talk about the pain that probably exists in the life of the mother who had to walk away from her baby.  We try to keep the reality of "birthmothers" hidden, out of sight, out of mind.

This book is a collection of voices of original mothers.  There are many reasons why these women lost their babies and their stories together tell the story of adoption in the United States.   This project has two major goals.  The first is to untangle the myth of the "Birthmother."  There is too much myth built up around the identity of original mothers and the world needs to hear more truths.  The second is to facilitate the telling of these important stories .  The project offers women a legitimate place to tell their stories, some for the first time.  I believe it will also help families to heal. Helping moms tell their stories in open ways is healing and transforming.   Telling does not make the story go away, nor does it remove the trauma, but  it helps one to understand and forgive and gain a new identity, "the teeth" of the tragic event have been removed.   

The only way to heal a hurt is to give voice to what ails us.  It is only in this way that we can keep our pain and loss from taking root inside us.  It is only in this way that we have a chance for freedom.  Desmund Tutu (97)

In this collection you will meet women like Vicki, Cathi, Fritz and Haley. Vicki's story is painful to hear, as a 19 year old she tried her hardest to do the right thing by her infant son and her step children.  She was left to mother five children with little support.  Pressure placed upon her by partners and a state agency drove her to give up and try to kill herself.  Instead of providing support and a little know how, instead of offering a place where she could learn to parent, find resources, gain a sense of self confidence, she was harangued until she finally signed over her rights.  Sixteen years later her eldest son found her again in order to remove himself from an abusive adoptive mother.

Cathi was raped at 14, and according to her mother, that was her fault.  Fritz found herself pregnant at 20 in a relationship and very aware that they had too many needs of their own to be good parents, yet.  She grew up with a mentally ill Mom, she knew what bad parenting was like, she intentionally researched and found what looked like an ideal adoptive situation for her to surrender, yet it was not an easy process. And Haley's story is quite different and as she says in some ways the happy ever after adoption story.  Even so it outlines the on-going pain that surrounds losing a baby.

A third unplanned benefit is that reading the stories in total offers a new understanding of the history of adoption over the past seventy years.  Seen in chronological order one has a window into the ways policy and society dictated adoption and maintained shame.

It is rare for the voices of original mothers to be collected and shared.  Ann Fessler in 2006 pioneered the collecting of this unique population's stories, a few have followed.  This one will  show the history of adoption over the past 70 years and how adoption has effected society over the years.  Giving a baby to adoption is not the courageous selfless action of a "drug addict whore."  It is a complicated decision made by women who are under stress and being pressured from many different directions.  It is a heart wrenching event in both mother and baby's lives no matter when in history it happened.

Adoption continues to be riddled with stories of trauma and coercion.  It is necessary for the truth to be clearly stated.  It is important for society to honor the stories of original mothers.  This book's intention is to paint that picture, to allow women to tell their stories and for the public to get beyond the rhetoric of adoption.

The oldest woman in this collection just turned 80.  She was born in 1935 and relinquished her child in 1955 at birth.  The youngest woman in this collection is 27.  She relinquished in 2005.  Their stories are very different, yet they contain some similar variables.  All of these stories describe the brokenness that walking away from one's own baby produces.  Different women refer to this "brokenness" in different ways. 

Nancy describes the endless wondering, the fact that she never stopped worrying about and wanting to know if her daughter was searching for her, needed her.

Pam describes;  My life up to that point had been secure and stable and predictable.  And after David, it was not secure, it was not stable and any predictability was just what I brought to it.

Meg states, "It is a daily struggle to try to get the birth into some kind of perspective and achieve some normalcy in my life, especially since there are so many complex and diverse emotions in play from anger, both at myself and others, to guilt."

The belief was that they would just get over it;  it was best for mother and baby to be separated as quickly and with as little interaction as possible and they would both "move on."  Not one of the women I interviewed, no matter what her circumstances were, have described any of the experience as just moving on.  This is a myth of relinquishment and it has been maintained for many years.  In this collection of interviews they are all in agreement,  no one just moved on.

For Pam there was always a "Kind of alien disconnect."  A big deep dark secret that hovered in the background of all decisions; she never felt quite stable in her life.  Fritz says, "First few years were the toughest.  I was distracted, suicidal..."  Cathi expresses her sadness and her regret which maintains to this day. 

The idea that "you would forget" was an horrendous lie and all thought something was intrinsically  wrong with them because they were not forgetting the baby or the birth, or they had no memories of the experiences, a total black out around it.

Adoption has gone through a slow change and continues to change.  Presently there are original mothers and adoptees who feel adoption should be illegal, that it is society consciously causing trauma to a mother and a child.  Others feel adoption can be an option if handled with care, but none of the women in this collection buy into the idea that" adoption is a beautiful courageous thing."  It maybe a last resort, an important option for some people, but policies surrounding it need to be revamped considerably and money needs to be funneled into helping women and men learn how to parent.  This book will help to illuminate some of the issues that are so important to a large portion of our population.

Often I get asked why I believe I am the right person to take on this project.  To begin with I am an original mother.  I relinquished my daughter when I was 19 in 1972.  My own story will be included in the book .  I know what it feels like to be broken and to learn to live my life with relinquishment as a part of the components that make up me, a part of my identity.

I am a writer and a photographer.  I have the skills needed to complete this project  I am an experienced interviewer and  researcher and have read extensively in the field of adoption.

I am also passionate about this project and have dedicated my life to if for the past nine months.  I have submerged myself in "adoption world," while trying to understand the lenses of all the different players in the triad: original mother, adoptee and adoptive parents.

Description of Process

1. Over the past nine months I have interviewed over fifteen women who have relinquished a baby to adoption.  The women I have interviewed have ranged from ages 27-80.  They have relinquished between the ages of 14 and 23. I have 3 more interviews lined up.  These interviews, with the exception of two, have been done over the phone.  The interviewee were sent the questions prior to the interview call.  I tried to connect by phone with each person to talk to them and answer any questions about the process. 

2. Each story is being written up based on the interviews drawing from each woman's voice with the goal of maintaining the individual voices.  I have written a third of the stories, thus far.  After the first draft is completed each woman will receive her story in order to provide feedback and make any changes they see as important.

3. Thus far I have interviewed everyone over the phone with the exception of the two who live near me.  I think it is essential to meet each woman and to add portraits and illustrations to the book.  My vision of the completed project includes story, voices and photos and helps to define adoption from the perspective of original mothers.  To do this I need to make 2 trips, one across from the east coast to the west coast and one down the east coast.  After completing the first drafts of all of the stories by the end of September, I would like to spend from the middle of October to the middle of November on the road. During one of the trips I would like to attend the CUB* conference retreat  in Carlsbad, Ca.. ( *CUB is a national association for concerned birthparents.  This is the annual national meeting of the association.)

At each stop I foresee each woman able to have input on her own story, on the text of her story: to make suggestions for illustrations, memorabilia, old photos one might include and to do a picture shoot.  This face to face meeting will also give me a chance to follow up on any holes I perceive in the manuscript.

 4. After I return home I will put together the complete book including photographs and text.

5. I will then give the manuscript to an editor and work with that person to refine the book.  All writers need good editors.

6. Once I have a completed draft I will share it with contacts of publishers I have been collecting along the way.  If nothing comes from these contacts by January first I will go for further funds to self publish the book.

 BUDGET

I am looking for $15,500. to finish the process of creating/writing this book.  This sum will enable me to finish without interruption. 

1) Salaries  author $8,600 for 4 months expenses

  editor = $2,100.

2) Travel - $4,000.

3) Conference fees and costs - $500

4) equipment and materials - $300

·  It will provide me with the funds to pay a professional editor.  All good writers need good editors.

·  There is a need for some extra equipment including extra memory card and back up batteries, an off camera flash and a small point and shoot for more informal photos, to be less intimidating while collecting photographs on the road.

·  It will allow me to attend CUB conference. Concerned United Birthparents is the national association focused on resources and support for original parents.  Attending   $500 Oct. 23=25

·  And it will cover my living expenses at a minimum so that I can continue to dedicate myself to the project

I foresee each woman able to have input on her own story, on the text of her
story: to make suggestions for illustrations, memorabilia, old photos one might
include and to do a picture shoot.  This
face to face meeting will also give me a chance to follow up on any holes I
perceive in the manuscript.
 4. After I return home I will put together the
complete book including photographs and text.
5. I will then
give the manuscript to an editor and work with that person to refine the
book.  All writers need good editors. 
6. Once I
have a completed draft I will share it with contacts of publishers I have been collecting
along the way.  If nothing comes from these
contacts by January first I will go for further funds to self publish the book.
 BUDGETI am looking for $15,500. to finish the
process of creating/writing this book. 
This sum will enable me to finish without interruption.  
1)
Salaries  author $8,600 for 4 months
expenses
  editor = $2,100.
2) Travel -
$4,000.
3)
Conference fees and costs - $500
4) equipment
and materials - $300
·  It will provide me with the funds to
pay a professional editor.  All good
writers need good editors.
·  There is a need for some extra
equipment including extra memory card and back up batteries, an off camera
flash and a small point and shoot for more informal photos, to be less
intimidating while collecting photographs on the road. 
·  It will allow me to attend CUB
conference. Concerned United Birthparents is the national association focused
on resources and support for original parents. 
Attending   $500 Oct. 23=25
·  And it will cover my living expenses
at a minimum so that I can continue to dedicate myself to the project

story:
¿Qué?

Último deseo es una novela cargada de esperanza, que aborda de un modo magistral el tema de la aceptación de la muerte. Tanto de la propia, como de la que se ha de llevar a un ser querido.
Último Deseo narra la historia de Ena, una joven que sufre de una rara enfermedad que empeora a ritmo vertiginoso. Sus ganas de vivir y la lucha con la muerte, que mantiene una presencia constante en la obra, inspirará a sus seres queridos a reinventar sus propias vidas y a aventurarse a cumplir sus últimos deseos por ella. Ena, acompañada en este viaje por su hermana Alicia,  su madre Isabel y su abuela Ayana, encontrará la fuerza para honrar las últimas oportunidades de vivir que la vida la presenta.

Una novela que aborda la muerte sin prejuicios, sin el velo de la religión y con la valentía de quienes la ven acercarse desde lejos. A través de sus personajes, el lector se adentra en los recovecos mas profundos del alma, donde el miedo, el amor, el odio, la pasión o la amistad se vuelven universales.

¿Quiénes?

Tandaia es una joven editorial con voluntad de cambio, de dar la alternativa a autores que no la encuentran en otro lugar, con nuevas y refrescantes ideas como es el crowdfunding.

De este modo eres tú, ahora que te estás planteando cómo colaborar, el que decide si la obra que te presentamos verá la luz pasando a formar parte de nuestro catálogo... porque consideramos al lector parte fundamental del proceso.

Hoy te presentamos a Inés Alonso de Vega.

Nacida en Madrid en 1984, aunque a los pocos meses su familia se trasladó a Tenerife. Regresó a Madrid en 2002 para iniciar sus estudios de Arte Dramático, donde años después co-fundaría la compañía Zas-Boing Teatro. En 2012 se graduó en "Ciencias Politicas y de la Administración" por la Universidad Complutense. Un año mas tarde, presentó su tesis de máster "Incidencia política para el desarrollo. Estrategias de movilizacion social" en el Insituto Ortega y Gasset. A finales de 2013 emigró a Canadá en busca de mejores oportunidades laborales.

Siempre inmersa en la vida cultural madrileña, Ines participó en la escritura de varias obras teatrales y ensayos políticos. Ahora presenta su primera novela, una historia llena de esperanza.

Inés Alonso de Vega, irrumpe en escena con una obra potente y excepcional.

¿Cómo?

Para arrancar el proyecto nos hemos fijado como objetivo 850€; esta es la cantidad que recaudaríamos si alrededor de cuarenta mecenas se hiciesen, cada cual, con un ejemplar de esta primera edición.

  • Teniendo acceso a las galeradas de edición.
  • Recibiendo un ejemplar semanas antes de la salida al mercado de la obra.
  • Si bien, también podrías ver tu nombre en los agradecimientos aportando un poco más.

Los fondos recaudados, se utilizarán para sacar adelante esta primera edición de Último deseo que saldría pocas semanas después a la venta.

Además...

Sabemos que son tiempos difíciles, también nosotros los sufrimos, y es posible que no te encuentres en disposición de apoyarnos con tu mecenazgo en estos momentos... pero esperamos que si esto te ha llegado al alma, incluso si tal vez conoces en persona al autor, trates de difundir esta campaña (facebook, twitter, blogger, boca-oreja... ) para que alcancemos nuestra meta y Inés Alonso de Vega vea publicada su obra.

Gracias por vuestro tiempo.

story:
My first successful Indiegogo campaign made it possible to publish my memoir, My Life a Four Letter Word, Confessions of a Counter Culture Diva. Over 110 friends, fans and kind strangers made it possible, and my first book reached over 10,000 readers and made it a #1 best seller for 48 hours on Amazon in the category of Memoirs of Entertainers. I have been resisting the idea of hitting you up again for more donations but who am I to deny the generous?

Now my boomer readers who are practically blind from aging are asking for an audio book too. So I plan on using a portion of these funds to produce the audio book of My Life a Four Letter Word for the visually and mentally impaired. Just like my once glorious double D’s, my first book sales are sagging a bit but that doesn’t mean I’ve been resting on my laurels.

I am also launching my new web series to build my brand, The Counter Culture Diva’s Naked Truth and soon you will be seeing me nude on television. Get out your glasses for that one and while you are at it, get out your credit cards.

I need even more of your funds now to support the publication of my second book, Blow Jobs, A Guide to Making It In Show Business, or NOT!

For a small contribution I promise you more laughs with a new book and a new opportunity to give. Blow Jobs will pick up where I left you in my first memoir,

As a loose whore in Show Business, I went from Dean Martin’s Maid to a Bimbo’s Slave to a pubic hair trimmer in XXX films. This book is a "How Not To"  filled with stories that burst the bubbles of Hollywood dreams. It takes you up and down the ladder of my hilarious trips and falls and delusions and brings you right up to date revealing the fate of this aging Counter Culture Diva.

This is a cautionary tale and not for the squeamish or faint of heart. It’s for those readers who wanted more of "My Life". In side splitting, juicy autobiographical stories I unleash the truth and nothing but the naked truth in BLOW JOBS, A Guide to Making it in Show Business or NOT! 

And there is more….

Take a look at the amazing perks you'll be rewarded with. Everything for cheap tricks to sugar daddy's pleasures.

Your donations can help make Blow Jobs even more popular than what Monica Lewinsky offered us in the '90s.

If you find yourself wanting to give but can't afford a dime, no worries, you can still help me by spreading two of my four letter words, by sharing my campaign on your social media outlets. Please use the the Indiegogo share tools, and or live links on my website's buzz page too, www.counterculturediva.com

And that’s all there is to it.

Bio: I've been a Counter Culture Diva and performer since 1970. I was mentored by the legendary Divine, and debuted with the infamous gender-bending Cockettes. I wrote and performed with White Trash Boom Boom, a girl’s group who wowed the boys in the San Francisco gay bars, and performed the same shows for women behind bars in California state prisons. Today I live in Venice Beach and continue to write and act in TV commercials and film, while promoting my daughter Viva's singing career.

story:
Bonjour à tous,

Je m'appelle Alain Truffier (Alias Angelstar) et je suis le créateur de plusieurs jeux en ligne dont 650km.com et Druidik.com.

Ce projet de financement INDIEGOGO permet de maintenir 650km.com en tant que jeu gratuit en ligne sans abonnement et sans blocage de niveau.

Cette page INDIEGOGO vous permet de faire vos contributions en toute sécurité et de recevoir vos KM-POINTS sous 48 heures après le crédit des achats sur le compte de 650KM

Je vous invite à mettre à jour vos informations personnelles dans 650km.Com afin que je puisse faire la liaison entre le contributeur INDIEGOGO et le joueur de 650km!

Grâce à ces fonds il me sera possible de maintenir le jeu en ligne et de m'assurer que les serveurs soient toujours opérationnels.

Il est désormais possible d'utiliser vos cartes de crédits ainsi que vos comptes Paypal pour obtenir des KM-POINTS!

Alain Truffier / Angelstar

story:
Synopsis

A young girl discovers a dark force, one older than man itself, that will send her world spiraling out of control. 

Introduction

Hello! My name is Chris Marquez. I'm a second year college student pursuing a career in music. I have two cats, love video games (my personal favorite being Halo), live with my family though I go out of town for college, and absolutely love fiction!
 I have always loved reading and have always enjoyed the worlds created by others. The stories of adventure, of strife, of love, of mystery and magic, have always captivated me so I decided to try my hand at creating my own world that people can enjoy, that people can relate to and love though it stretches into fiction. I decided to build characters and ideas that people can feel attached to.
Everyone who sees this post, whether or not you want to contribute, you are a part of building this world. A realistic yet fictional world, of trials and danger at every turn. You are the ones who will decided if this world goes on, and if gets out there for everyone to see. I pray that you will help me out on this journey, and even if you don't want to, thank you for even reading this!

What We Need & What You Get

Now to get to the nitty gritty stuff...
In total we'll need around 2,000 dollars to help fund the project. Not for my personal benefit, but to put towards editors, designers, sponsorships, advertising, proofreading, and finally publishing it. The first book of the series, Rise, will be self published, hence where we need the help since we lack the funds, and then we'll see from there where the rest of the series goes. Its a chunk of change, but we need it to get this book out.
If you donate you can say how, You, helped this series come to life. You can brag, or tell your friends and family how you helped a book come to life! 
On the other side of that, as an additional benefit, If you donate X amount of money you will receive a certain perk!
$5- Personal thank you on our Facebook page.
$15- copy of the finished ebook before its official release date with exclusive preview of the first chapter of Book 2!
$25- signed soft  cover version of Book 1, Rise.
$50- signed hard cover version, and Skype call with yours truly, where you can ask whatever you want about the series and I will try my best to answer! 
$100- Your name in the acknowledgments section of the book, because you will have made this book possible! 
$350- A character will be named after the contributor, and you will receive a signed hard cover version of the book.
Now its realistic that we may not reach $2,000 but, even if we don't the funds will still go to publishing the book and will be used to its best potential.

The Impact

This series is meant to be realistic, to pull you in and to help you understand and feel for the characters. To understand their pain and to be as realistic as possible in their situations. There will be pain, hardships, but there will be fun, happiness, and of course the hope that in the end good will prevail. 

I know it sounds like every other series out there, but its not. Other series almost everyone survives. Not many people die, theres always good winning at the end. This series will not go that path. It will be different, deaths, pain, suffering, but its realistic. 

Apocalyptic scenarios will always have death, and this series is no exception, still we will root for the goods guys to prevail, to triumph over the evil. 

With Vampires, humans, angels, werewolves, ghouls, wraiths, all living in our modern world, secretly of course, they will all have to face something far more deadly than anything we've ever seen before. Something that will show that even vampires and werewolves, have something to fear.


    Risks & Challenges

    There will be risks to this venture. I could fail to sell it, fail to catch the eyes of readers. The series overall could be discarded, but what series hasn't faced that threat?

    I believe, if done right, with the right editors, designers and proofreaders, that this series can be BIG. That it can rise above its competitors and steal the imaginations of thousands of readers everywhere. 

    Through insight, planning, careful reading, advertising, and of course a bit of help, I can make this happen. With your help, we can make this happen.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't donate, thats totally ok! 

      Instead, you can like our Facebook page, 

      https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Infinite-Saga/492434064222888?ref_type=bookmark
      Or, you can just get the word out of the series and this campaign! After all we need all the help we can get! There are share buttons on this site so just a click could be all we need!
      Thank you so much for your time, and for anything you donate or like! You are the building blocks of this series and I will not forget your help!

story:
Short Summary

Guess who's coming to the South? Love, GIRLS Magazine!!

Love, GIRLS Magazine (LGM) is a free quarterly publication distributed in Quad Cities, Memphis, TN, Washington, DC/Maryland/Virginia and Georgia (April 2015). Our four core principles are represented by LOVE, which stands for Lead, Overcome, Value and Empower.

LGM was started in 2012 by Jasmine Babers, then 15 years old, to support a friend who was experiencing emotional bullying. Since starting LGM, Jasmine has been recognized nationally for her work to empower girls including the 2012 White House Council on Community Solutions SparkAction Winner, Build-A-Bear Workshop 2013 Huggable Hero, Let Girls Lead 2014 finalist, Prudential 2014 Illinois Volunteer of the Year, and USA Characters United. 

What We Need & What You Get

The GA edition is making its debut in less than 6 months. We need YOUR help to make it grand!

Why we need your support? 

  1. Funding (contribute to our campaign)
  2. Graphic design work (t-shirts, flyers, posters, magazine)
  3. Doubling our printing (3,000 copies)
  4. Acquiring office space
  5. Rebranding our website (www.lovegirlsmagazine.com)

We are growing and so excited about bringing some LOVE to Georgia. Our plan is to kick-off Georgia in January 2015 with an announcement party and the first Love, GIRLS Magazine - Georgia edition will drop April 2015. The GA and DC editions will share content so your support HERE supports BOTH!!

    Some of our amazing perks:

    • LGM souvenir items range from pens, note pads, notebooks, tote bags and t-shirts.
    • LGM 2015 Calendar with a young girl of your choosing for a featured month
    • Ad Space in our premiere and anniversary issues
    • LGM featured model perk* is for the Fall Issue, a girl (ages 12-18) will participate in our Fashion Forward photo shoot. We supply the clothes, hair, make-up and photographer - she just has to show up!

The Impact

Love, GIRLS Magazine (LGM) was started to to help a friend deal with the effects of bullying! In three short years, it has expanded to Tennessee, Arkansas and the Washington, DC metro area. LGM is designed to help teenage girls build self-esteem, become leaders, and pursue their dreams.The DC magazine has impacted almost 10,000 girls.

The DMV Edition launched January 2014 and has engaged thousands of girls across the tri-state area. We plan to do it bigger and better in Georgia! 
Some major DMV accomplishments:
- Engaged over 25 girls that are now published journalists and/or artists
- Spring 2014 Cover girl, Gabrielle Jordan, was selected as the 365 Black Award Youth recipient
- Hosted our inaugural DC Love Awards recognizing four outstanding girls in the areas of Performing Arts (Kamerin Harris), Entrepreneurship (Danette Makaila), Community Service (Lauryn Boucree), and Leadership (Layla Fawaz). DC Grammy Association Board of Trustees member, Deborah Bond, served as the Host Committee Chair.


Help us start a success list for the GA Edition and contribute today!

Here is what our DMV contributors have to say:

Being on the work force of a magazine requires dedication. Be prepared to give time, it will be very worthwhile. With LGM, I have written book reviews, interviewed authors, written poetry (poetry! I didn't even know I liked poetry), and seen the behind-the-scenes work of publishing a magazine. LGM has opportunities to connect with people, expand one's literary horizons, and discover unrecognized talents. The time I've spent with LGM has been an amazing learning experience.                                                                           - Rachel, high school senior

LGM has taught me to love who I am. There is no limit or boundary to where and who you can be. I've met so many inspiring young women that give me motivation. Inspiration has no age; Jasmine Babers, who is the creator of LGM and one year younger than me, is amazing.

I was one of the cover model's and spokes person of the first issue of the D.C. issue. Also, I had the opportunity to attend the 2014 Love, Awards in Illinois because of LGM. These experiences changed me by giving me more drive for life. Everything that I've learned from LGM and the people involved had an incredible, positive toll on me. I've become more confident in what I believe and want to achieve for my life goals. I plan on being apart of the LGM team as long as I am able to. I want to inspire young women to be individualistic and leaders of their generation. I know that sharing my relatable story in life and with the LGM family will inspire many young and even older women to achieve the impossible. 

                                                                             - Keona, Premiere Issue Cover Girl

Your contribution will help us build stronger, more confident girls - one story at a time.

Risks & Challenges

 Our biggest challenge is that we are a free magazine and want to stay that way. Our girls are passionate about writing and making a positive impact. We risk disappointing them if we don't make our goal.

The risk for us is working so hard and pushing the girls then we don't publish the magazine. Our commitment is driven by the girls who put so much energy and time into making the magazine a success.  Every thing we do and all funds collected will support that effort and commitment. 

We do risk losing that opportunity if our funding efforts aren't successful. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need volunteers willing to serve in a variety of areas. Some of them include:

  • Writing Mentors
  • PR/Marketing Support
  • Community Outreach & Engagement (Maryland)
  • Community Outreach & Engagement (Virginia)
  • Special Events Coordinator
  • Copy Editor
  • Graphic Designer

If you want to volunteer, please complete this form.

Love, 

GIRLS!
story_txt:
Short Summary 
Guess who's coming to the South? Love, GIRLS Magazine!!
Love, GIRLS Magazine (LGM)
is a free quarterly publication distributed in Quad Cities, Memphis, TN, Washington, DC/Maryland/Virginia and Georgia (April 2015). Our four core principles are represented by
LOVE, which stands for Lead, Overcome, Value and Empower. 


LGM was started in 2012 by Jasmine Babers, then 15 years old, to support a friend who was experiencing emotional bullying. Since starting LGM,
Jasmine has been recognized nationally for her work to empower girls including
the 2012 White House Council on Community Solutions SparkAction Winner,
Build-A-Bear Workshop 2013 Huggable Hero, Let Girls Lead 2014 finalist,
Prudential 2014 Illinois Volunteer of the Year, and USA Characters United. 

   What We Need & What You Get The GA edition is making its debut in less than 6 months. We need YOUR help to make it grand!
Why we need your support? 


Funding (contribute to our campaign)
Graphic design work (t-shirts, flyers, posters, magazine)
Doubling our printing (3,000 copies)
Acquiring office space

Rebranding our website (www.lovegirlsmagazine.com)


We are growing and so excited about bringing some LOVE to Georgia. Our plan is to kick-off Georgia in January 2015 with an announcement party and the first Love, GIRLS Magazine - Georgia edition will drop April 2015. The GA and DC editions will share content so your support HERE supports BOTH!!

Some of our amazing perks:



LGM souvenir items range from pens, note pads, notebooks, tote bags and t-shirts.

LGM 2015 Calendar with a young girl of your choosing for a featured month

Ad Space in our premiere and anniversary issues

LGM featured model perk* is for the Fall Issue, a girl 
(ages 12-18) will participate in our Fashion Forward photo shoot. We 
supply the clothes, hair, make-up and photographer - she just has to 
show up!
 
  The Impact 
Love, GIRLS Magazine (LGM) was started to to help a 
friend deal with the effects of bullying! In three short
 years, it has expanded to Tennessee, Arkansas and the Washington, DC 
metro area. LGM is designed to help teenage girls build
self-esteem, become leaders, and pursue their dreams.The DC magazine has impacted almost 10,000 girls. 
The DMV Edition launched January 2014 and has engaged thousands of girls across the tri-state area. We plan to do it bigger and better in Georgia! Some major DMV accomplishments:- Engaged over 25 girls that are now published journalists and/or artists- Spring 2014 Cover girl, Gabrielle Jordan, was selected as the 365 Black Award Youth recipient- Hosted our inaugural DC Love Awards recognizing four outstanding girls in the areas of Performing Arts (Kamerin Harris), Entrepreneurship (Danette Makaila), Community Service (Lauryn Boucree), and Leadership (Layla Fawaz). DC Grammy Association Board of Trustees member, Deborah Bond, served as the Host Committee Chair.

Help us start a success list for the GA Edition and contribute today!

Here is what our DMV contributors have to say:Being on the work force of a magazine requires dedication. Be prepared to give time, it will be very worthwhile. With LGM, I have written book reviews, interviewed authors, written poetry (poetry! I didn't even know I liked poetry), and seen the behind-the-scenes work of publishing a magazine. LGM has opportunities to connect with people, expand one's literary horizons, and discover unrecognized talents. The time I've spent with LGM has been an amazing learning experience.                                                                           - Rachel, high school senior

has taught me to love who I am. There is no limit or
boundary to where and who you can be. I've met so many inspiring young women that give me motivation. Inspiration has no age; Jasmine Babers, who is the creator of LGM and one year younger than me, is amazing.

of the D.C. issue. Also, I had the opportunity to attend the 2014 Love,
Awards in Illinois because of LGM. These experiences changed me by giving me more drive for life. Everything that I've learned from LGM
and the people involved had an incredible, positive toll on me. I've
become more confident in what I believe and want to achieve for my life goals. I plan on being apart of the LGM team as long as I am able
to. I want to
inspire young women to be individualistic and leaders of their
generation. I know that sharing my relatable story in life and with the LGM
family will inspire many young and even older women to achieve the impossible. 
                                                                             - Keona, Premiere Issue Cover GirlYour contribution will help us build stronger, more confident girls - one story at a time.

The risk for us is working so hard and pushing the girls then we don't publish the magazine. Our commitment is driven by the girls who put so much energy and time into making the magazine a success.  Every thing we do and all funds collected will support that effort and commitment.

story:
WE DID IT!!!!! Thank you to all of our SUPERSTAR supporters!

Who Am I?

Hi, my name is Pauch Khiev. I am the author of Purging Innocence. I was born in Cambodia during a horrific time in history. I was barely one year old and still breastfeeding when the Khmer Rouge tore me from my parents who were forced into hard labor. I was left alone with two older sisters, one a 5 year old and the other barely 8 years of age. Mystically, a beautiful LEOPARD appeared nightly to sleep under our stilt house as if it was sent from heaven to be our guardian angel. I emigrated to the United States with my family in 1981.


What Is This Project About?

In 2008, I began my lifelong dream writing my book about my family's journey through the Khmer Rouge Regime. The Khmer Rouge killed anyone that was affiliated with the government, military officials, doctors, lawyers, students, teachers, and even those who wore glasses because they were suspected to be intellectual.

I interviewed my brother, San Khiev, an ex-military soldier, who was arrested, interrogated, then tortured in a pagoda temple called Wat Thomayuth. At least 80 prisoners were executed daily as he miraculously escaped death numerous times. He is the only known survivor. 

After the evacuation from Phnom Penh on April 17, 1975 people gathered in the countryside along the Mekong River. San had the privilege to share a part of his life with a famous Cambodian singer, Sinn Sisamouth, known as "The King of Khmer music" who is equivalent to Elvis Presley. While a prisoner in Wat Thomayuth he developed a special bond with an actor named Tuk Kom from the Cambodian movie Veal Srey Sroh Noh.

Each day prisoners marched into mass graves as San clung onto his BLUE KRAMA (SCARF) praying for miracles. The blue fabric was awarded to him for a successful productive season in the Palm Plantation. San brought the fabric along when he was arrested. The fabric became a lucky charm that shielded him from the evil eyes of the Khmer Rouge.

The interviews were recorded and spoken in our native language. After 5 years of crafting and translating it into English, I have finally finished.


How Is This Important?

My book is important on many levels.

  • Documents the existence and the importance of the roles my family had during a historical time.
  • Each book written about the the Khmer Rouge Regime, the author becomes a voice for the victims that can no longer tell you what happened to them or for those who are too frightened to speak of the painful events.

  • My hope is that history does not repeat itself.

Millions of innocent people were executed and many lives were turned upside down. And many people are still recovering from this very tragic time in Cambodian history. This is a poignant story about my family's journey. A true story of loss, survival, and triumph of the human spirit. It is an honor to be able to share it with the world.


How Can You Help?

Please help make my dream come true! Make a contribution!

I am looking to raise $4000 to help with the costs of self-publishing and marketing this book. I am very hopeful that I can get to this goal with everyone's help!

Self-publishing requires a considerable investment in order to get the book online at Amazon, Barnes and Noble, etc. Although it will cost more than what I am asking for, the funds received will help with a small portion of the costs.

What Do You Get?

There are many great perks to choose from. You can pick up an autographed copy of the book [hoping for 2014 release], have your name featured as a superstar supporter on our upcoming website, or even stay warm during the cold winter months with a lucky royal blue hand knit scarf.

Look on the right for all the cool perks available. Some perks are limited so act fast!

*** 12/19/13: PERKS ARE NOW AVAILABLE FOR THOSE LIVING OUTSIDE OF THE USA. PLEASE ADD $10 SHIPPING FOR ORDERS OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES. THANK YOU!

We tried to edit the Perk descriptions to say this but Indiegogo.com does not allow any changes to perks that have been claimed by a contributor. Nonetheless, It's now open to all!

The Impact

Your contribution will truly make a difference. This campaign will only succeed with your help!

Your contribution will be helping a great cause:  

  • You will be helping to get this book become available online (and I will work hard to try and get in brick-and-mortar bookstores).
  • I will be donating a portion of my proceeds from book sales towards helping families in Cambodia who are less fortunate and for the preservation of Big Cats.

You'll be able to follow along on charity work as we will update our website. For those who want to volunteer and participate in future events, dates will be available.

Your donation can help change lives!



Other Ways You Can Help

I know not everyone will be able to contribute financially. If you are unable to, you can still help out tremendously! How? Spread the word and share this campaign on Facebook (and don't forget to "LIKE" us), Twitter, blogs, websites, etc. Just use the Indiegogo share tools. Tell everyone about this! This will help bring more awareness to the campaign and book. Every little bit helps!

Thank you from the bottom of my heart for your support. Happy Holidays and may your New Year be filled with abundance!

with abundance!

story:
Our Story

On October 27th 2011 I am bringing some great poets up to Albany NY to read. Now, I said 'great." I did not say filthy wealthy. There's a reason for the term "starving poet."  I am talking about prize winners, professors and authors of several books. I am not talking about Wall Street tycoons. 

The Impact

You can't put a price tag on what people like this bring to our community when they bring poems of provocation, inspiration and witness. 

What We Need & What You Get

But the poets need gas money. And maybe a sandwich and a cup of coffee while they're here, too. I am not asking for a billion dollar bailout here. No Siree. But I bet that in 18 days I can make $300 to cover gas, food and lodging for some very, very special out of town luminaries. That's a tank of gas both ways (fifty bucks each way), a night in a clean hotel or motel (another fifty to seventy each) and some lunch money. Go ahead. Make my day. Show me the money. ;) If we can make our goal of $500, I can book another poet or poets to come up next!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please come to Bonobo Cafe at 174 Madison Avenue in Albany (zip 12202: Google it!) October 27th at 7 PM for the spoken word event of a lifetime. We will also have music by Taina Asili, artwork by Marcus Kwame Anderson, and DJ Trumastr will spin some music to help you shake it loose after the show.


AND SHARE THIS FUNDRAISING REQUEST LIKE A RUMOR. Ask everybody for fifty cents to feed and gas up some good poets.

story:
My Story

When I was a little girl I used to think I would grow up to become an artist.  I believed I would one day wow the world with my doodles and colored designs!  This fantasy, of course, was fueled by winning a Safeway coloring contest when I was ten.  Walking into the store to receive my reward--knowing I'd come in first place!--was the start of something big!  Just so happens, it was the same year I discovered I could write.


Turns out I had a gift, or so my fifth grade teacher told my parents on Parent/Teacher Conference Night.  Should this have come as a surprise?  Probably not, but boy was I glad to hear it!  For my gift gave reason for my constant daydreaming.  It explained my incessant need to direct play dates with my cousins. Cut! Listen guys, it's not working. Where's the drama? The suspense? When I say "..." you should say "...," and put some feeling behind it.  Now let's take it from the top!


To hear I had a gift changed my life, and my ambitions.  Book signings.  The New York Times Best-Sellers list.  An Oscar Nomination.  A Pulitzer Prize in Fiction.  These weren't just dreams.  They became my expectation for greatness; an indication of the success that lied within me.  But somewhere along the way I began to lose hope, to question myself and believe the lies.  I asked myself, Who am I to be worthy of such a gift?


It wasn't until I met the man in my dreams that I began to feel worthy, intelligent and capable of achieving the so-called impossible.  So if you have ever questioned yourself or your talent, then my heart goes out to you.  I know what it's like.  But it doesn't have to be this way.  No one, not even you, should ever feel or be made to feel unworthy of their gift.  And while these doubts know no gender--as a woman and founder of Her Nation--the her inside of me cannot allow the her inside of you to believe another lie.  We are far too precious to hide our light from the world.


The Impact

Nearly six months ago, I sat down at my computer and began to write a blog. I'll be honest with you. The idea of blogging used to scare me.  I mean, what was I going to say?  What did I need to say?  And, why would anyone care to read it?  But to my surprise, I knew exactly what I was going to say and why I needed to say it.  I was so excited, I was willing to share how I became my her with anyone who would take the time and read.  Little did I know the blog would reach 27 other countries in a matter of weeks.  With just the same interest, I began to receive posts on my Facebook Page from women in other states and countries, each believing they were alone in their quest to become their her.  Suddenly I was not alone.  I was not the only one.


Can you imagine?  Have I just discovered my purpose?  When what I'm gifted to do aligns with my passion to help others?


Even within my own network of friends, I began to ask, "Do you have a her?"  It took six months and an embarrassing amount of tears to write, When I Am Her.  Not only because of its content but because I knew--for the first time in my life I really knew--that this wasn't just about me.  This was about a nation of women.  A Her Nation.


The impact?  I've witnessed firsthand how much a woman can overcome when she discovers the her within.  There is courage, strength, passion and a sense of worth that cannot be tainted or taken away.


My hope is BIG and asking for help (especially when it pertains to money) doesn't come easy for me.  But I cannot make this a Her Nation alone.  I will plant the seed.  I will hold their hand.  I will hug them when they cry.  And I will stand with them when they are weak.  But I need you.  I need your support.


What We Need & What You Get

To be fully funded would mean I could print 2000 copies of When I Am Her and work on getting the book into independent bookstores and universities world-wide.  So long as I'm dreaming BIG, I will continue to pursue other outlets, such as Starbucks, Costco and Target.  But I won't stop there.  Your contribution will help market and promote the book (via our website, Facebook, Twitter, etc), create branding materials (such as apparel and stationery) and make workshops available to women incarcerated and/or suffering from abuse.


Most importantly, you don't have to be a woman to help.  Turns out we all have a mother, sister, or friend who could use a lil' her pick me up, every now and then.  And to show my gratitude, I've created some rather nice perks.  Especially with New Year's Resolutions right around the corner!  So take a look and know you're not just making my dream come true.  You're helping another woman discover their her and show the world what she is made of!

Please note:
* To print 2,000 copies of the book has an early eta of January 2012.
* All perks include UPS Ground shipping within the United States.
* For interest outside the US, please email Her Nation at: info@thehernation.com
* If I am not fully funded I will use the funds raised to continue my efforts in making this a Her Nation. 


Other Ways You Can Help

1) Word of mouth is always the best campaign.  Watch the video and let your family, friends and co-workers know about Her Nation (the campaign, the book, our mission and ways in which they can help).  Remember, we all know someone who could use a lil' her pick-me-up every now and then!


2) To pre-order copies of the book or other Her Nation products outside of Indiegogo, please visit the Her Nation store: 

http://www.thehernation.com/#!shop-hn


3) Become a fan on Facebook:

http://www.facebook.com/pages/When-I-Am-Her/146...


4) Follow the blog: www.wheniamher.blogspot.com


xoxo,

from one her to another

Most importantly, you don't have to be a woman to help.  Turns out we all have a mother, sister, or friend who could use a lil' her pick me up, every now and then.  And to show my gratitude, I've created some rather nice perks.  Especially with New Year's Resolutions right around the corner!  So take a look and know you're not just making my dream come true.  You're helping another woman discover their her and show the world what she is made of!


Please note:
* To print 2,000 copies of the book has an early eta of January 2012.
* All perks include UPS Ground shipping within the United States.
* For interest outside the US, please email Her Nation at: info@thehernation.com

* If I am not fully funded I will use the funds raised to continue my efforts in making this a Her Nation. 



Other Ways You Can Help
1) Word of mouth is always the best campaign.  Watch the video and let your family, friends and co-workers know about Her Nation (the campaign, the book, our mission and ways in which they can help).  Remember, we all know someone who could use a lil' her pick-me-up every now and then!

2) To pre-order copies of the book or other Her Nation products outside of Indiegogo, please visit the Her Nation store: 
http://www.thehernation.com/#!shop-hn

3) Become a fan on Facebook:
http://www.facebook.com/pages/When-I-Am-Her/146...

4) Follow the blog: www.wheniamher.blogspot.com

xoxo,
from one her to another

story:
¿Qué?

Los Feedlebag te adentrará en el espectacular paisaje de Los Picos de Europa... en compañía de unos seres misteriosos, que te verán aunque tú no los veas a ellos.

Ana y los gemelos Pedro y Lolo se dirigen a un campamento de verano en Los Picos de Europa. Allí nada es como esperaban. A Ana le toca compartir cabaña con “La vampiresa” y dos chicas más con las que no tiene nada en común. El único que le gusta desde un principio es Marcos, el monitor, guapo y simpático, quien les cuenta la increíble historia de Los Feedlebag. Aunque muy escépticos al comienzo de la narración, pronto descubrirán que hay más de verdad de lo que parecía.

Nuestra protagonista siempre supo que su llegada al mundo tenía un propósito, un sentido, en esta aventura lo descubrirá por fin, se convertirá en el viaje de su vida y conocerá por primera vez el amor. Eso sí, nada es lo que parece en un principio.

¿Quiénes?

Tandaia es una joven editorial con voluntad de cambio, de dar la alternativa a autores que no la encuentran en otro lugar, con nuevas y refrescantes ideas como es el emplear una campaña preventa para valorar la aceptación y viabilidad de cada título.

De este modo eres tú, ahora que te estás planteando cómo colaborar, el que decide si la obra que te presentamos verá la luz pasando a formar parte de nuestro catálogo... porque consideramos al lector parte fundamental del proceso.

Hoy te presentamos a Beatriz Cerón Morales.

Nacida en Málaga en 1974, donde se licenció en Filología Inglesa, también tiene estudios de Filología Hispánica y en la actualidad trabaja como profesora de Lengua y Literatura en un instituto de secundaria. Ha sido finalista en numerosos certámenes y ha obtenido algunos premios literarios entre los que destacaríamos el Primer Accésit en la XXVI edición del Premio Joaquín Lobato con el poemario Máscaras, músicas, mares y juegos y el Primer premio del XV certamen de poesía Victoria Kent con el poema Versos blasfemos. Los Feedlebag es su primera novela juvenil.

Tal y como anuncia en su blog vitaenverso.blogspot.com.es su bisabuelo era encuadernador y siempre ha imaginado que este hecho marcó que las letras corrieran por sus venas y se tomase la vida en verso.

¿Cómo?

Para arrancar el proyecto nos hemos fijado como objetivo 800€; esta es la cantidad que recaudaríamos si alrededor de cincuenta mecenas se hiciesen, cada cual, con un ejemplar de esta primera edición.

  • Teniendo acceso a las galeradas de edición.
  • Recibiendo un ejemplar semanas antes de la salida al mercado de la obra.
  • Si bien, también podrías ver tu nombre en los agradecimientos aportando un poco más.

Los fondos recaudados, se utilizarán como ayuda para sacar adelante esta primera edición de Los Feedlebag que saldría después a la venta.

Además...

Sabemos que son tiempos difíciles, también nosotros los sufrimos, y es posible que no te encuentres en disposición de apoyarnos con tu mecenazgo en estos momentos... pero esperamos que si esto te ha llegado al alma, incluso si tal vez conoces en persona al autor, trates de difundir esta campaña (facebook, twitter, blogger, boca-oreja... ) para que alcancemos nuestra meta y Beatriz Cerón Morales vea publicada su obra.

Gracias por vuestro tiempo.

story:
Lunar Mama Craftworks is a small, parent owned etsy shop that sells handmade herbal breastfeeding support kits for breastfeeding parents. Owner, Kait Moon is a Volunteer peer support counselor for breastfeeding families, a birth and breastfeeding rights activist and a mom to four awesome kids and blogger and writer. She has been supporting parents in their birthing and breastfeeding goals since 2012, after the unexpected hospital birth of her twin sons.

After leaving the hospital she struggled to feed her twins, primarily due to poor support in the hospital. After three months of often depressing and painful setbacks they were both able to breastfeed full time. It was an extremely challenging experience for her and her family but the knowledge and resources she gained were invaluable. As the twins grew, Kait began offering breastfeeing support services, for free, as a volunteer peer counselor to parents who were struggling. Her first hand experience, years of research on herbs, breastfeeding and biology, and access to libraries of information and resources are used to create tailored support for each family, according to their particular circumstances, something often overlooked in providing breastfeeding support, all free of charge.

Kait is the writer behind The Imperfect Wife, a blog with info and resources for all things related to parenting. The blog and peer support lead her to create the Herbal Breastfeeding Kits and inspired Kait to write a breastfeeding guidebook. She also produces art and written work under the umbrella of "The Lunasea".

This is where you come in.

In order to publish the book Kait needs to pay for editing. She is currently in the Literary Kitchen (where her blog began!) editing and refining the book's contents and has formatted the book as a quick reference, small, easy to read and hold guide.

This campaign also aims to raise funds to help her cover costs of enrollment in an Herbal Medicine for Women certification program by an internationally known educator Aviva Romm. This will enable her to reach more families with healthful, holistic information by hosting workshops as a Certified Educator.

All of this will support her in offering outstanding, well rounded products as well as low cost exemplary education and workshops for parents and birth workers in support of birthing and breastfeeding families. Your contribution will have not only an impact on the parents she is able to reach but their children and future generations that will have access to this life changing, and in many cases life saving information.


Follow the money!

Your contribution will go directly to the following expenses. This is the bare minimum to move to the next step in providing these services to women in need. All funds received above the goal will go directly to expenses related to this project (More herbs! More childcare! More printing!) :

Certified Women’s Herbal Educator course $2150
Associated expenses (books, some of the supplies) $300
Workshop for Editing of book $300
30 hours of childcare @$10/hr $300
Publication of book (self-publication - run of 250 w/shipping) $800
Fees associated with this campaign 4% of total, approximately $200 (If I meet the goal, or 9% if I do not meet my goal)

Grand total: $4,050


What you get in return.

Depending on the level of contribution you'll be able to pick up a signed copy of her book, A Lunarmama craftworks tote bag, sticker and card sets, limited edition postcard sets and prints featuring original art by Steph Davies, MoonCat, Daniel Rathbun, Emily Schwank of Raincliffs Photography, Ellen Weistra and Shawna Schwalenburg of LotusFly Photography, a Tea for Two herbal kit or travel mug kit from Lunar Mama Craftworks, and other great items yet to be announced. Plus you'll get your name on the website and blog as a contributor when you donate $5 or more and your name in the acknowledgements of the book when you donate $1 or more! That's right if you donate even one dollar you will be thanked in my book!


What happens if the goal is not reached?

Because this is a flexible funding campaign all donated funds will be retained by Lunar Mama and used in the following ways:

If we do not reach our goal, all funds minus the 9% fee that must be paid to indiegogo (the fee is reduced to 4% if we reach the goal) will go to the publication of the book and any left over funds will be added to a savings account to help eventually pay for the Education Certification Course. Kait is bound and determined to hone her craft and offer her services to breast-feeding families and their allies. And as always she'll continue to offer her peer support free of charge. This is the first step of many.


Be the Change.

Breastfeeding is often much more difficult than most parents are lead to believe. Lack of information and support plays a huge roll in the low rates of breastfeeding in America. Despite the overwhelming scientific evidence of the vital impact breastfeeding has on cognition, brain development, long term physical and emotional health and secure bonding for parents and babies, families and health workers are misled and even lied to about the crucial role breastfeeding plays in long term health.  Empowering parents in understanding their bodies and their inherent abilities, offering education on their options and providing resources and support is vital to parent health, infant health and ultimately world health.

Kait has had had hundreds of hits on her blog post on breastfeeding since it was published in August 2013, all through word of mouth. She has offered her support, free of charge, to dozens of families to establish/reestablish and maintain their breastfeeding relationship with their babies and her kits have been sent to several states including Texas, Washington, Wisconsin, and Colorado. They are also sold at the retail shops The Waxwing and The Sparrow Collective, Near Milwaukee and are now available at 8 Branches Chinese Medicine in Bay View, WI. Local birth centers and other retail shops have expressed interest. We feel that providing a more detailed guide book and workshops would allow her to reach parents directly and in larger groups, helping more families, and facilitating more peer support through community outreach. The demand is there. Help Kait boost the supply with nourishing support and healthful education.

If you cannot contribute financially, please consider sharing this with your breastfeeding groups on social media, with your mama and papa friends, their families, your doulas, doctors, nurses and midwives and all birth workers. Anyone you think would be willing to spread the word or donate a dollar or two to helping parents and children succeed in one of the most beneficial, life changing and vital acts of parenting. How we feed and nurture our children. Every share helps this campaign by boosting our visibility and every single dollar goes directly to this important and life affirming cause.

Image (c) Elly Weistra. This image and many other are featured in the "Love Letters" Incentive!

story:
The Intro + Summary

My name is John Rich. I am a writer, performer, and arts administrator in Chicago. I am proud to serve as Director of the Guild Literary Complex, a live literary arts presenter celebrating 25 years of cross-cultural programs.

This indiegogo campaign is an extension of my personal commitment to literary arts and social justice. I have been invited to attend the International Cities of Refuge Network (ICORN) General Assembly in Ljubljana, Slovenia from May 21-24, 2014, in order to learn from other cities how Chicago can become an official safe haven for authors endangered by politically motivated threats or persecution.

ICORN has been an independent international organization since 2010, and before that existed as a loose network of member cities. ICORN member cities host threatened authors and their families for two years or more. There are currently over 40 ICORN member cities, but only one member is a US municipality (Miami). Chicago enjoys an long tradition of significant literary and social justice activity. Making Chicago an ICORN member city is only fitting, and a vast cultural network will be engaged. In time, that network can harness funding support and other contributions. But today, I need your help.

Thank you for considering making a donation towards realizing Chicago (and the United States) as a refuge for threatened authors, and thank you for your interest in the preservation and promotion of Free Speech.

What I Need & What You Get

The invitation to attend the conference came recently, and ICORN is providing a personal grant of 1000 Euro ($1380 USD) to help make my participation possible. That will cover more than half of my expenses, and I hope to raise $1020 via this indiegogo campaign. When I return, I will begin to connect with other Chicago area institutions to share my experience and lay a framework for our region’s inclusion in ICORN.

Here’s where the money goes:

    $1500 Round Trip Airfare
    $900 Hotel

This is a Flexible Funding campaign, which means I will receive funds collected even if I don’t meet my goal, but when I meet (or exceed) my goal I pay a smaller fee for the indiegogo service. Any funds over the goal will be used towards food, local transportation, and any incidentals from the trip – including post cards from Slovenia sent to you for donating $25!

Check out the other perks, including one where I come to your organization or business and talk about my trip, ICORN, and making Chicago a City of Refuge. Or if you’d rather, I’ll give you and your group an interdisciplinary workshop on creativity, a version of a class I teach at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, and you can explore your own voice!

The Impact

Each ICORN city focuses on one writer at a time, each writer representing the countless others in hiding, in prison, or silenced forever. By providing a writer (and often their family) with a safe place to stay and economic security for a standard term of two years, ICORN cities make an important, practical contribution to the promotion of Freedom of Expression.

This invitation and vision of Chicago as a City of Refuge grows out of the work of the Guild Literary Complex. This month (April), the Guild is presenting the work of two poets who benefited from the assistance of ICORN: Mazen Maarouf from Lebanon/Palestine and Manal Al Sheikh from Iraq. It is part of a series called Voices of Protest, which will also include several young Chicago authors attending Kapittel International Festival of Writing and Freedom of Speech in Norway this September, and the publication of a volume of creative work and essays related to the themes of the project: contemporary Middle Eastern poetry, protest, suppression of speech, exile, words bearing witness, and words as agents of change.

Voices of Protest, though a separate project, has many related goals related to making Chicago a City of Refuge. In both cases the intent is to increase awareness of the plight of threatened authors; cultivate a fellowship between international writers in exile and writers in Chicago; develop audience a shared global literature; inspire civic engagement on free speech and human rights issues; and build cultural bridges. All of this work remain necessary and vital.

Other Ways You Can Help

I hope you can contribute, but there are other ways to get involved.

Please share this indiegogo on your social media. And if you are in Chicago, please check out the ICORN author programs the Guild Complex has planned for 7pm on Friday, April 25 and 8pm on Saturday, April 26. Mazen Maarouf and Manal Al Sheikh will be reading at Facets Multimedia (1517 W Fullerton) both nights, and the Guild is  screening excerpts from Poets of Protest, an Al Jazeera produced series that focuses on six Middle Eastern authors, including Mazen and Manal. More information is available at www.guildcomplex.org.

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary:

After listening to MandoPony's wacky and hilarious 'Horsefamous', a strange thought crossed my mind: Why not write a satirical book about the 'famous' people of our wacky little fandom? Right now I'm working on two separate books. One, a humorous and completely (un)true look at the hidden world of the horsefamous bronies we all know and love. The second? A heartfelt look into the fandom examine the pros and cons of our little family. The second will be an autobiographical format, where I explain all the nitty-gritty of how I joined the fandom, what happened at conventions (including the popularly untalked about Las Pegasus), and how the group is evolving as time progresses. I'll be completely honest about all topics, including a few stories that are downright embarrassing.

What We Need & What You Get

I need dat dosh, mang! Dat green! Dat paper!

Seriously, any amount will help this project. The order of importance goes as this: Medical check-up (potential migraines that effect my vision), printing of the book into a physical format if demand is high enough (Found a company that will do it for $300) , and cash for convention travel.

The Impact

You'll be able to either:

1) If utilizing my autobiographical book, go behind the scenes of our fandom to see the best and worst we've done.
2) If utilizing my satirical book, become horsefamous and perform the correct ceremony and rites to appease ***************** so that ******************.

Risks & Challenges

If the goal isn't hit, the books will be made available digitally with the option for the reader to pay what they wish for them. Want to donate $10000? Groovy, you got two books! Want to donate $0? You still get two books! But one would make me a bit more happy.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about this project and contact me with VERIFIABLE information about brony conventions if you worked behind the scenes of them. You'll be credited if your information is proven accurate and featured in my book.
story_txt: Short Summary:After listening to MandoPony's wacky and hilarious 'Horsefamous', a strange thought crossed my mind: Why not write a satirical book about the 'famous' people of our wacky little fandom? Right now I'm working on two separate books. One, a humorous and completely (un)true look at the hidden world of the horsefamous bronies we all know and love. The second? A heartfelt look into the fandom examine the pros and cons of our little family. The second will be an autobiographical format, where I explain all the nitty-gritty of how I joined the fandom, what happened at conventions (including the popularly untalked about Las Pegasus), and how the group is evolving as time progresses. I'll be completely honest about all topics, including a few stories that are downright embarrassing.   What We Need & What You GetI need dat dosh, mang! Dat green! Dat paper!Seriously, any amount will help this project. The order of importance goes as this: Medical check-up (potential migraines that effect my vision), printing of the book into a physical format if demand is high enough (Found a company that will do it for $300) , and cash for convention travel.   The ImpactYou'll be able to either:1) If utilizing my autobiographical book, go behind the scenes of our fandom to see the best and worst we've done. 2) If utilizing my satirical book, become horsefamous and perform the correct ceremony and rites to appease ***************** so that ******************.  Risks & ChallengesIf the goal isn't hit, the books will be made available digitally with the option for the reader to pay what they wish for them. Want to donate $10000? Groovy, you got two books! Want to donate $0? You still get two books! But one would make me a bit more happy.  Other Ways You Can HelpSpread the word about this project and contact me with VERIFIABLE information about brony conventions if you worked behind the scenes of them. You'll be credited if your information is proven accurate and featured in my book.

story:
Hi, my name is Pam. In November 2012, a bunch of my friends were doing National Novel Writing Month. This is an annual event where The Office of Letters and Light challenges participants to write a 50,000 word novel in one month. I was unemployed. The job search wasn't going well. I had nothing else productive to do, so I decided to join my friends and write a book. It was the best decision I could have made. While writing, I was focused and even happy. The result of that NaNo was Oblivion. Oblivion is the story of six New York City acting students striving to find success while learning what it means to live in oblivion. One of the themes in Oblivion is following your dreams.  Publishing this book would be following one of mine. 

I have decided to self-publish, which means the onus for all production costs is on me. Your contributions will go towards funding a copy editor and publishing costs. Any money left over will cover marketing. The only things I can offer as perks are book previews and Indiegogo exclusive content. All perks unless otherwise noted will be in PDF format. 

And if you have a group, you might want to consider entering to Compete for Best Ensemble. The group that raises the most money gets a shout out in the book's acknowledgements. All groups are eligible. To sign up. click here .

If you are unable to contribute, please pass this campaign along to your friends.  Any and all efforts will be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your support! 

Pam

story:
Free Radical Radio is an anti-civilization anarchist podcast and radio show. Every week for almost two hours, broadcasting as part of the Berkeley Liberation Radio (BLR) Collective in West Oakland, Free Radical Radio has brought thousands of listeners thoroughgoing anti-civilization analysis and direct action news.  

Decidedly anti-journalistic, FRR makes no pretense of adhering to the mythical and undesirable nonsense of "journalistic objectivity". Instead, the hosts - Rydra, Bellamy, and Doug, along with occasional guest hosts - make clear their views and thus speak passionately and unequivocally on all topics, pushing past any ill-conceived notions of impartiality and instead pursuing sincere and subjective critique and analysis. Topics are diverse, especially in light of the show's intentionally improvised nature (another intentional revolt against the excessive formality and stifling rigidity of traditional journalism), but include: anti-civilization critique informed by anarcho-primitivist and egoist theory; unapologetic vitriol toward Leftist currents of "anarchism" and other civilization reformism thinly veiled as "revolutionary movements"; digest and editorial on world news and events; commentary on radical activity in the Bay Area; resistance worldwide and our frank take on what is being done and what might be done differently, with a special focus on current eruptions (such as the recent events in Ferguson, MO: https://archive.org/details/RevoltInFerguson); horticulture, forest gardening, intentional communities, rewilding, primitive reskilling, and other activity on the "constructive" end of anarchy; and interviews (released regularly in addition to the weekly show) with authors, organizers, resisters, rewilders, and others.

Free Radical Radio is celebrating its one-year anniversary. Starting as a casual vent-session by Bellamy and Rydra, FRR has grown into a more deliberate and concerted effort to create a much-needed venue for discussion of anti-civilization theory. As we get ready to release a series of in-depth interviews with friends of the show as well as new voices, we also look to the future with a desire to get new equipment that would help us continue and better our project. Having reflected on our first year, we want not merely to maintain but in fact redouble our efforts to expound on anti-civ theory, showcase rewilding and horticulture projects, and tell stories of ongoing revolt: look to our recent interviews touching on everything from riots against police in Salinas and Ferguson; gentrification battles in Oakland; land struggles such as the ZAD and the Albany Bulb; and anarchist writers, thinkers, and doers such as Natasha Alvarez, John Zerzan, Franklin Lopez, Kevin Tucker, and an upcoming conversation with Wolfi Landstreicher to get an idea of what is to come.

Aware of the irony of asking for funds for technology, we nonetheless believe we can improve the anti-civilization discussion with a modest sum of $2,000 that would be used to acquire better microphones, a laptop, and other equipment to improve the audio quality of regular recordings and interviews. Our most frequent complaint from listeners is that they have trouble listening to our sometimes lousy audio quality that stems from our extremely limited equipment, particularly if they have less-than-stellar audio equipment themselves. In addition, we would like to have our own website in order to reduce our dependence on odious social networks, better organize our media, and make space for new efforts like blogging or video down the road. Every bit will help in this pursuit, even if we don't reach our goal.

For transparency's sake, we are happy to inform everyone who contributes exactly how we spend the funding - we will e-mail everyone with budget updates explaining what we spent and why. 

We hope that the hundreds of people who download and listen to our show every week can help us meet this goal. We are suggesting a donation of ten to fifty dollars, depending on what individuals believe is practical given their resources and desirable given their interest.

We hope that contributors, as with all listeners, will contact us at freeradicalradio@riseup.net to give us feedback (positive or negative), suggestions on how to improve the show, and information on potential interviewees (including themselves). We look forward to continuing to work hard to produce content that makes an impact.
