story:
A poetic glimpse into the heart of the American Factory Town

We are raising funds to publish a limited edition of A PLACE IN TIME, a poetic memoir that captures the sights, the sounds, and the spirit of the American factory town.  Poet David Kherdian takes us back to his roots as he recounts what it was like growing up in Racine, Wisconsin--home to countless factories, including J.I. Case (heavy equipment), S.C. Johnson (cleaning and chemical products), and Dremel.  

We need your help to print the special edition--a book that you will be proud to display on your bookcase.   A 5.5" x 8.5"  clothbound hardcover will include over 300 pages of poetry and prose dedicated to the American factory town and all those souls who made it so special.  Just like the heavy equipment once (and still) manufactured in Racine, we want this book to stand the test of time.

Extra funding will support the creation of the e-book version of A PLACE IN TIME as well as assist the production of animations set to reading of David's poetry.

 

A memoir like no other...

As David effortlessly moves between prose and poetry, he creates a poetic memoir like no other.  He starts at the edge of town, on the shores of Lake Michigan and slowly brings us to the heart of Racine.   Once we've reached Racine's downtown, David takes a deep dive into the most overlooked aspect of any factory town - the people who call it home.  His friends, his struggling parents, the town drunk--David pays loving homage to all of them.  And in doing so, he gives us a key to unlock our own memories that we may have been on the verge of forgetting.  Even though this is David's memoir, his flowing verses give us the ability to explore our own thoughts that we ourselves believe to be long gone.  

 

 

The Grape Arbor

The Grape Arbor is a poem that truly captures the vibrant spirit of the American factory town.  Despite the long hours and difficult work, David's father always made time to tend to the grape arbor in their back yard.  In the midst of the omnipresent smoke, fire, sweat, and tears, a grape vine rises up from the ground -- providing comfort and grace for all who sit under its shade.  

 

Even though this poem is tied to his own personal childhood, David's grape arbor easily morphs into any symbol that grounds us to our hometown--perhaps a BBQ grill, a picnic table, or swing-set.  

 

The Grape Arbor

In the grape arbor built by the German

couple who owned the house before

I was born—directly behind the house

and in front of our small garden,

we had family picnics, my mother had

tea with her lady friends,

I cleaned all the fish I caught,

and sometimes read a book,

and met with my friends;

and where my sister later had

her birthday parties—

 

Is there still

in all the photographs and silent memories—

a touch of beauty, a measure of grace

in the hardest of circumstances

that helped to keep all things

in balance.

It was special, it was ordinary.

It was, after all, us.

and we put our mark there

and however our torn lives may be dispersed

it will always be there,

stamped on our only coin, with which

we barter for more of this difficult

demanding life.

An artist's interpretation of David's GRAPE ARBOR, set to a backdrop of Racine's factories

 

A Message from David

Our love of place can continue even when gone, because in America this love of place existed; our nostalgia and sentimentality for our homes bears witness to this, and this is what my book brings into focus, because we had a home once, that we must now create for ourselves, even when it is gone but still standing yet in remiss, and this we can accomplish from memories remaining from the place and time we came from.  When this love is realized and remembered from one place, it becomes transferable, in that our present place can remind us and return us to our lost place, emboldening us to reinvent ourselves and not lose what we once had. The power of art, of literature, of writing, can be a great help in this, for we need examples, models, and pioneers of the spirit to walk with us and carry us forward on our journey.

Please help us bring this memoir to life and help us capture a part of ourselves that must not be forgotten.About the Author 

David Kherdian, born in Racine, Wisconsin, is the author and editor of over seventy books, that include poetry, novels, memoirs, biographies, retellings, and children’s books.  He was awarded the Newbery Honor for his THE ROAD FROM HOME.

story:
Who are the 89ers?

The 1989 Generation, or ‘89ers’, are the generation that has grown up in a Europe that is united and free from the imminent threat of war. We are the generation shaped by Erasmus, EasyJet and the Eurozone. We are also the generation of new threats, the sudden upsurge in extremist ideologies, both on the continent and abroad, and of mass migration from Asia and Africa.

We have often been accused of indifference, disunity and political apathy. Yet ultimately, this is the generation upon which the responsibility of European leadership will soon rest, as we will be the ones who will ultimately define the long-term future of the European Union.

The 1989 Generation Initiative is a European policy start-up organisation committed to mobilise the 89ers to lead the long-term regeneration of the European Project. Our ultimate goal is to foster broad consensus on a new direction for Europe across generations and disciplines.

Combining elements of think tanks and social movements, we develop innovative policy proposals through a unique process of outreach and intergenerational dialogue, underpinned by cutting-edge research.

We are currently based at the European Institute of the London School of Economics & Political Science, where we have been established in February 2015 as an associate organisation. Since then, the Initiative has quickly grown to 50 staff from more than 20 countries and over 100 participating members.


27th April 2016: Writing the next chapter

Our first flagship event took place in June 2015 at the LSE. Young Europeans from all member states participated in a conference alongside top-class academics as well as EU and officials, including:

  • Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, former French President
  • Timothy Garton Ash, Professor of European Studies at Oxford University
  • Sir Christopher Pissarides, 2010 Nobel Prize-winning economist 
  • Neil Kinnock, former Labour Party leader and VP of the European Commission
  • Fabrizio Saccomanni, former Italian minister of Economy and Finances
  • Karen Smith, Director of the European Foreign Policy Unit, LSE IR Department
Since then, the 89ers have been hard at work perfecting 8 policy proposals for reforming the EU, across four sectors:
  • Politics and Institutions
  • Economic Affairs
  • European Identity
  • EU as a Global Actor
The proposals have been developed in collaboration with the visionary thinkers present at our June workshops, and this work supported by leading think tanks, such as Centre for European Policy Studies, European Policy Centre and the Clingendael Institute.

Our proposals will be enshrined within the 'Manifesto Redefining the Future of Europe' and presented in a major event on 27 April 2016, at the European Parliament in Brussels.

What do we need?

We would like to crowdfund the costs of the printing of our Manifesto, which will enable us to distribute it amongst political and academic institutions across the continent. 

This will allow us to raise awareness of our work, and gather support around our policy proposals, which are meant to improve the lives of all Europeans. Our most competitive quote for printing costs is £2.30 per piece, and we would like to print at least 250 copies of our manifesto, bringing the costs to £575. The remainder of the amount will go into postage costs as well as promotional materials for our Event.


Other ways you can get involved

We'd love to hear your ideas about which national and European institutions we should send a copy of our Manifesto to. Please drop us an email with your suggestions at social@1989generationinitiative.org.

You can also sign up to our monthly newsletter and stay up to date with the latest from the 89ers!

story:
Funding Follow That Arrow

Gourmet Gwen here, food blogger and lover of words. Help me publish my first book. After leaving my home in Hawaii due to very unexpected circumstances, I went on a great, big journey. From driving across the United States, to walking the Camino de Santiago pilgrimage, I stumbled through finding a new life. This book is just another leg of that journey, and I need your help to make this dream come true. Please consider contributing to cover the costs of publishing, your reward being of course, a copy of the book. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • It costs about $5000 to self-publish a book. This includes editing, cover design, formatting, project management and all the little things like registering a trade name and buying an ISBN. 
  • By contributing, you will be the first to get your hands on the book, this is your chance to pre-order. And depending on how much you can contribute, I will send perks like hand-blended teas and sweet treats. Big contributors will expand my book touring options by bringing me to your town. 
  • If the entire goal is not reached, all funds will go toward publishing costs. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Once you've read the book, it would be a big help if you could write a review on Amazon, Good Reads, or wherever you get book reviews. 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word about this campaign.
  • Spread the word! Find me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
